/COMMIT_MSG.message: agree
is it required?

From a protocol standpoint, a response is valid if it contains either, so this is what the generic checks need to do once we unify them to support their existing callers (case where they check for content-length) and the new callers (that exercise swift code that responds with transfer-encoding only).

We could be stricter and mandate either Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding but prevent having both, but the HTTP specs seems to not really ban this, and this would I think be too zealous.

tools/check-cherry-picks.sh.message:
The second ascii diagram in the git-merge man page [1] seems to show why it's always the 2nd parent that we want (A is the first parent, C is the second parent):

      A---B---C topic
     /         \
D---E---F---G---H master

[1] https://linux.die.net/man/1/git-merge

Note to self: NF (without the $) is the number of fields in the current record.

Example with two parents:

$ git show --format='%P' --quiet
f644da10b28336496fe8f59d43fcdb3a77d7ea13 a45daafd3111a6804eb5adafe4860db122cb09b8

then

$ git show --format='%P' --quiet | awk '{print NF}'
2

Note to self: $NF (with the $) is the last field in the current record.

Example with two parents:

$ git show --format='%P' --quiet
f644da10b28336496fe8f59d43fcdb3a77d7ea13 a45daafd3111a6804eb5adafe4860db122cb09b8

then

$ git show --format='%P' --quiet | awk '{print $NF}'
a45daafd3111a6804eb5adafe4860db122cb09b8

neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py.message:
I'm ok with this patch but IMO the correct way to solve this issue, like with other binding objects, is to link the DvrFipGatewayPortAgentBinding object to the Agent GW port, not to the GW itself.

Doing this, when the port is deleted, the binding is deleted too. I'm talking about something like this: http://paste.openstack.org/show/795497/

Of course, this change is more complicated. But the result is more elegant and we ensure, via the DB backend, that the binding object will never survive the port deletion.

Binding to agent_id is to aviod the multiple fip gw port creation, the uniq constraint is "network_id" + "agent_id", so each one binding can ensure there is only one gw port. If change it to "network_id" + "port_id", one same agent clould have more than one fip gw port in same network. That is the orignal code expectation.

neutron/privileged/agent/linux/utils.py.message: pep8: N341: _ from python builtins module is used. Use _ from neutron._i18n instead.
just curious, why not using ip_lib.IPWrapper?

IPWrapper will call SubProcessBase._execute, that will call linux.utils.execute that will call create_process (non root, we are already in a root env), that will call subprocess_popen

This is already implemented and maintained in processutils and used by other projects like Nova. We can skip implementing those functions in Neutron if we have this common library.

Totally agree that the role of unstack.sh is unclear.

I have no strong reason to use unstack.sh but I use it from the following two reasons:
- clean.sh deletes devstack log (/opt/stack/logs). I would like to keep recent devstack logs so I use unstack.sh.
- Another reason is to skip several package installation like rabbitmq, mysql and so on, However it is not a major factor on how long stack.sh takes now, so it is a matter of taste.

In a short term, what I expect in unstack.sh is that all services works properly without digging into detail like the issue here when we do stack.sh -> unstack.sh -> stack.sh.

In a long term, it sounds reasonable to drop the current unstack.sh and use clean.sh for all cases.

clean.sh claims to be for cleaning up after grenade runs, so having unstack.sh clean up everything that devstack does seems the right thing to do. one might argue that stack.sh in itself doesn't create any instances, though.

on a more general note, I think we should deprecate unstack.sh completely. we don't properly test it and if we could agree that ppl should just use throwaway instances for running devstack like we do in gate, things would get much simpler.

I agree. what exactly unstack.sh supposed to do is not very clear. It cleanup few resources and leave few.

As long term benefits, I agree with Jens to deprecate it and keep the single cleanup script clean.sh only.

specs/backlog/periodic-task-mode.rst.message: typo: the
Cannot these tasks be done in an async way?

One thing I do not understand.

What we have now is a single conductor process choking at times at slow tasks. This proposal implies that having two conductor instances would eliminate or relax this bottleneck. But where exactly is the bottleneck? Can we just raise the limit on concurrently executing tasks within a single conductor process? Either way we get the same computational load on the server, it seems...

May be worth explaining why proposed separation is better than bumping up the concurrency limit.

We're using eventlet, i.e. greenlets. This means, all our concurrency happens on one core, no matter what. Futurist, the underlying library we use to run periodics, supports true threads and even processes to run the tasks. But we cannot quite use these features, because they're not compatible with the rest of the greenlet-based conductor. If we split away periodic tasks workers we can run periodics on a process pool that will utilize the CPU much better.

> And still, it's not true concurrency, so at some point the sequential Python code will start to matter as well.

Indeed. I am sort of hoping that if those greenlets fork fast and yield, we could have hundreds (?) of them before hitting the bottleneck there...

> As to ipmitool, we already have complaints that we run too many of them..

Could you please refer me to those complaints? I am interested to learn how many is too much. ;-)

> Greenlets are cheap, but how many ipmitool instances is safe to run simultaneously...?

They're relatively cheap, but not free. And still, it's not true concurrency, so at some point the sequential Python code will start to matter as well.

As to ipmitool, we already have complaints that we run too many of them..
I don't have a link handy, but I recall somebody displeased with dozens of ipmitool processes hanging around.

If I read code correctly, by default conductor might spawn up to ~100 instances of ipmitool concurrently.

I am thinking, would it make reasonable difference in performance if we do Python/greenlet bindings to ipmitool's library so that the concurrency won't involve spawning ipmitool processes...?

Although I am planning to research this ipmitool bottleneck to get somewhat more solid data.

specs/backlog/periodic-task-mode.rst.message:
So, there are two bottlenecks, and a lot of this is coming out of long term memory, so some details will be fuzzy.

Bottlenecks:

1) Maximum number of concurrent tasks with each periodic task consuming one of those slots.  I don't remember the exact numbers. This is problematic with the GIL effectively resulting that we only consume one CPU core.
1a) We presently have 14 periodic tasks, I think we by default have ?20? concurrent threads?
1b) On a plus side, 4 of those tasks are going away next cycle, although most deployments don't have those enabled by default.

2) Sync power state essentially constantly consumes workers by rolling through the enrolled nodes. Each power state check with ipmi results in an exec which holds that worker for up to several seconds. In a small scale, that is not a big deal, but at 1000+ nodes things are different.

So I should really just highlight that we would get true multiprocessor concurrency by running multiple processes?

I am trying to understand this:

We have a greenlets pool of 100 workers. We have periodic job for power sync which cycles over the nodes and spawns up to 100 greenlets to run semi-concurrently. Each greenlet eventually calls green `subprocess` to exec ipmitool.

Since it's a green `subprocess` it does not block the conductor thread where all these greenlets run. So we should end up running up to ~100 instances of ipmitool concurrently syncing power states for up to ~100 nodes at once.

Would it be a problem to bump up the greenlet workers pool size upper limit? Greenlets are cheap, but how many ipmitool instances is safe to run simultaneously...?

> I guess we're just CPU bound on a single processor at that point

I feel the need to research this. If we run ipmitool in a subprocess through a greenlet, I wonder what takes up so much CPU from the conductor process...

Anyway, would it help to improve scheduling if we:

* reduce `sync_power_state_interval`
* reduce `[ipmi]command_retry_timeout`
* increase `power_state_sync_max_retries`

In effect, periodic ipmitool threads/processes would live shorter, but conductor will ponder getting node power state for longer?

Can we see that the conductor process is indeed CPU-bound at that time? Your note elsewhere in this spec appears a bit contradictory saying that the controller is still underutilized. If it's the GIL thing, we should probably see at least one CPU/core fully consumed?

> With the consumption of the workers, on tasks that may 
> be in a wait state such as waiting for ``ipmitool``
> to return data, the CPU resources of the conductor are
> not being used to the most possible efficency. 
> This worsens the perceptions when dealing with the
> scale because the services appear to have free
> resources, but are unable to execute any faster.

does it really need to finish the hook entirely?, the rest of the configuration should be safe to be executed.

yep, there is no clear right or wrong, in general we try to allow to service running, so if a operator configures the charm to load the module "do-not-exist" then we should warn about the failure loading the module, but move on, since the rest of the system could be perfectly running.

Here it's an example where an operator could use badly configured settings that won't prevent the system from working -> https://review.opendev.org/#/c/715182/8/hooks/nova_cc_utils.py

Fair question that I had too; here's the story.

I didn't find a recommended behavior for the config-changed hook in case of incorrect settings (I see there is such for the relation-changed hook with incomplete settings, for example.)

So I asked in our team's channel, and been replied that this is implementation specific.

Thus I followed what is done a bit below, in the existing valid_plugin() check.

The intention I had in mind is to notify the user/operator early if a particular module in the list is wrong/fails to load; so that it doesn't go under the covers and turns into a harder problem to debug later on.

I imagined that with sys.exit(0) the 'blocked' state and the status message would persist, but they are cleared up once the status-update hook runs.

Really open to feedback and suggestions here.

Thanks for reviewing!

Thanks for explaining. Changed to a warning message only.

unit-neutron-gateway-0: 15:24:47 WARNING unit.neutron-gateway/0.juju-log Failed to load kernel module 'module404'

I am not familiar with modprobe error messages myself, but is it possible to have additional information here by printing the exception? Example:

    except CalledProcessError as e:
        log("Failed to load kernel module {}, error: {}"
            .format(module, e))

Thanks for reviewing.

Unfortunately the CalledProcessError exception in this case does not carry stdout/stderr from modprobe, because charmhelpers.core.kernel.modprobe uses subprocess.check_call() (instead of .check_output() or .run()) which does not store it.

Reference: https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.CalledProcessError

And by printing the exception as string, we only get the generic message of a non-zero exit code.

>>> try:
...     subprocess.check_call(['modprobe', 'module404'])
... except subprocess.CalledProcessError as e:
...     print("exception: %s" % e)
...     print("stdout: %s" % e.stdout)
...     print("stderr: %s" % e.stderr)
... 
modprobe: FATAL: Module module404 not found in directory /lib/modules/5.4.0-37-generic
exception: Command '['modprobe', 'module404']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
stdout: None
stderr: None

As a side note, checking on a particular exception type here would be an encapsulation violation to charmhelpers? Theoretically* that could change from subprocess to something else someday, and the particular exception type no longer be generated -- so I guess we cannot assume just one type here, and at least should have a catch all case.

If there's another way to implement what you suggested in the neutron-gateway charm, without changing charmhelpers for that, please let me know.  Python beginner here! :)

Thanks!

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/dataclasses.html

bond name is a required field per the networking model format (as in the way to describe the bond). If the bond is correctly described, it should be implemented as such. There was a discussion on how all the networking should be implemented, and Alessandro decided to have the policy that if one networking item cannot be set or is not supported, all the networking stack should immediately throw an error. The other option was to execute on a best effort basis.

The MAAS or OpenStack ways of describing the bonding partially coincide due to the Linux jargon used, but are not the same.

If there are any downstream-only patches in the repo, this might cause an issue.

In that case, the spec has the upstream tarball and some "Patch0001: xxx.patch" lines, which will not be present when creating the tarball from the downstream repo. As a fix, the best solution would be to set the following two options:

use_upstream_spec=true
downstream_spec_replace_list=^%global with_doc.+/%global with_doc 0,^%global rhosp.*/%global rhosp 1

With this, we will replicate the same method used by OSP Trunk.

@Daniel: yes, to answer your question... the tempest test uses a default security group with 2 ingress rules and that is what it assigns to the vms in the test if we do not specify one. They allow all local traffic, as shown in example below. That allows VMs to talk to their local dhcp server as well as metadata.

sg b986a6fe-a395-4a39-b655-0ce5b08cf5df -- 5cf8556f-2fce-408a-81b0-671170a05b76

应该是file://, 最后一个/ 是代表根目录，/localdisk/loadbuild

1, layer build以后， 需要打包到iso中的package，应该都添加到各自git project里的<os>_iso_image.inc里。  

2, compile 或者distro layer中增加 iso中的package，在这两个layer build结束后，执行如下命令生成各自layer 的image.inc

source build-tools/image-utils.sh
image_inc_list iso dev <layer> > my_<layer>_image.inc

cengna上的各自layer的 image.inc也是这样生成的。

在stx-tools/centos-mirror-tools/config/<os>/<layer>/required_layer_iso_inc.cfg文件

$ cat stx-tools/centos-mirror-tools/config/centos/distro/required_layer_iso_inc.cfg
compiler,std,http://mirror.starlingx.cengn.ca/mirror/starlingx/master/centos/compiler/latest_build/outputs/image.inc
compiler,dev,http://mirror.starlingx.cengn.ca/mirror/starlingx/master/centos/compiler/latest_build/outputs/image-dev.inc


修改成你的distro 或者compile layer的 image.inc
file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<user>/<project>/my_<layer>_imajge.inc


在build flock layer的时候会去读这个require_layer_iso_inc.cfg
或者下面的命令修改layer的image.inc
   generate-cgcs-centos-repo.sh \\
      --layer-pkg-url=distro,std,file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<my-project>-distro/std/rpmbuild/RPMS/rpm.lst \\
      --layer-pkg-url=distro,rt,file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<my-project>-distro/rt/rpmbuild/RPMS/rpm.lst \\
      --layer-pkg-url=distro,installer,file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<my-project>-distro/installer/rpmbuild/RPMS/rpm.lst \\
      --layer-inc-url=distro,std,file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<my-project>-distro/std/image.inc \\
      --layer-inc-url=distro,dev,file:///localdisk/loadbuild/<my-project>-distro/std/image-dev.inc \\
      /import/mirrors/CentOS/stx-r1/CentOS/


编译flock layer时候，会在cgcs-root/cgcs-centos-repo/layer_image_inc, 包含distro和compiler layer 的image.inc

build-iso的时候会被使用。

I'm still a bit hesitant to add this restriction to openstack/requirements repository, as kombu is used in other projects, too, but I don't see broken tests elsewhere.

[1] https://github.com/celery/kombu/pull/1193/commits/398aa5b8cd1fe1fc189ab35a2cb0bececf51bf37

Sure, but given how widely used oslo.messaging is if it doesn't work with a given version of kombu chances are deployers don't want to be using that version anyway. I think this is fair to add to global-requirements until there is a fix in kombu.

On oslo.service we faced some issues related to eventlet lower than 0.22 [1], that I fixed by upgrading eventlet to 0.25.2, so can we use this version here too?

Also I think it could be worth to keep synced versions of eventlet in use in oslo.

That's a fair point, however, lower-constraints is passing here so I'm tempted to keep this as-is. You'd be hoping everyone would be using the newest version possible in all cases anyway

Agree. If there is something that we know breaks with this specific repo using older versions, then we should definitely raise the lower-constraints to make sure we are correctly communicating to downstream what we expect to work or not. But if so, I'd rather see that done as a follow up patch as this one just attempts to refresh all of our lower constraints.

Some time value returned here could break because PATH value is not reliable. Because of that here I introduced a PYTHON_PREFIX=/usr variable to enforce where to look first before other places.

Thank you for your suggestion. 

I have a some question:) 

What is the mean of 'VDU state change'? resource change?
If it is right, it already supported by tacker.

In a case of hardware(VIM) fault, VDU which runs on that VIM also down. Current ping driver sends it to tacker and it tries to respawn about VDU. But, it can't due to the VIM fault..right?

Can I have more detail example?

The main requirement of this time is "event-based triggers". VDU state is only a parameter of triggers.

As you said, if VIM is completely failed, VDU is also down. But some users want to define their own failure.
E.g. if memory usage is continues to decreasing, treat VIM as failure before any issues occur.

Triggered by such prediction cannot be detected by current features because any issues do not occur yet. Such prediction is analyzed by external features (someone want to use AI...) and the features send just event. I think it is implemented as Aodh alarm.
